awd_titl_txt: Functional Analysis of Plant Carotenoid Dioxygenases
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the functions of a class of enzymes known as carotenoid cleaving dioxygenases (CCDs). These enzymes metabolize carotenoids, creating a vast array of economically important molecules. Some of the products of these enzymes, called apocarotenoids, also have biological activity in plants and animals. Important apocarotenoids include retinoids in animals, abscisic acid in plants, the major colorant and flavor compound in saffron, and major scent volatiles in roses. The investigators have focused on four CCD enzymes (CCD1, CCD4, CCD7 and CCD8). Two of the enzymes, CCD1 and CCD4 appear to function in synthesis of flavor and scent volatiles. They also have as yet undefined roles in carotenoid turnover. Loss of either of these two gene products significantly increases the carotenoid content of seeds. The project will address the functions of these two enzymes as it relates to carotenoid content with the potential to enhance the nutritional composition of some foods. Techniques for characterizing the biochemical activity of CCD1 were developed during the prior funding period. These techniques will now be applied to biochemical characterization of CCD4. CCD7 and CCD8  act coordinately to synthesize an as yet unidentified novel plant hormone that regulates the ability of the plant to make branches. A major goal of the investigators, together with collaborators, is to identify the biologically active compound synthesized by the CCD7/CCD8. In addition to isolation of the hormone from plant tissue, the biochemical properties and substrate preferences of CCD7 and CCD8 will be determined. A related goal is to characterize the natural variance within maize populations of CCD7 and CCD8. 

Broader Impacts: The project is expected to provide fundamental insights into the functions of the CCD enzymes. Understanding the roles of these enzymes in vivo has great potential to improve both flavor and nutrition of foods, especially in the developing world. The project also has the potential to identify an entirely new class of plant hormones that regulate plant architecture. This research is a platform to educate undergraduate and graduate students, including minority students from Fort Valley State University, an 1890 Land-Grant University.

por.por_cntn:
We have greatly expanded the knowledge of the biochemical action of the Carotenoid Cleavage Dioxygenases (CCD), enzymes that generate a wide array of molecules with multiple functions in plants ranging from hormone activity to flavor.

CCD1. We showed that this enzyme is capable of cleaving multiple linear and cyclic carotenoids (e.g., lycopene and beta-carotene). The enzyme can generate multiple apocarotenoid volatiles that are major contributors to tomato flavor.

CCD7. We had previously demonstrated that this enzyme is an essential component in the pathway for synthesis of a class of hormones, collectively known as  strigolactones (SL), that control lateral shoot growth and overall plant architecture. During the current funding period, we isolated and characterized the tomato gene/enzyme. We determined that the enzyme functions not only in synthesis of SL but also apocarotenoids associated with mycorrhizal fungal symbiosis.

CCD8. As with CCD7, CCD8 is an essential enzyme involved in synthesis of SL. We made significant progress in the characterization of the SL pathway in maize. Maize CCD8 was characterized and the pleiotropic roles of SL in maize development delineated by analysis of an SL-deficient mutant. A mutation in zmccd8 confers a relatively mild branching phenotype. Increased lateral bud length compared to wild type was evident in seedlings and axillary branch number was 2-fold higher than wild type at maturity. In addition to the branching phenotype, zmccd8 plants exhibited a syndrome of pleiotropic growth phenotypes including short stature, narrow stem diameter, delayed leaf senescence, yellow-striped leaves, altered ear morphology, reduced seed size and small root system. Although zmccd8 seeds were 22% smaller than wild type, zmccd8 kernels germinated faster than identically treated wild type seeds, indicating a role for SL in regulation of seed dormancy and/or germination.

We completed a study examining the roles of the apocarotenoid volatiles in tomato flavor. these volatiles are generated in part by the action of CCD enzymes. We used carotenoid synthesis mutants of tomato and a consumer panel that rated the fruits for flavor. Panel results showed that the apocarotenoid volatiles are essential to flavor. Mutants that do not synthesize subsets of these volatiles are deemed less flavorful. A particularly unexpected result was that fruits depleted in these volatiles were perceived as less sweet. This result indicates that the volatiles, sensed via the olfactory system, have the ability to alter perception of sugars, perceived by the taste system. This cross-talk between the two independent sensory systems was a major unexpected finding.

 

Broader Impacts:

Scientifically, the project provided fundamental insights into the functions of an important family of enzymes that are responsible for generating multiple biologically active molecules. We provided insights into the way plants regulate their architecture, the way in which they interact with the microbial community and the way in which they create chemicals that are essential to good flavor.

 We trained three minority interns from an HSBC, Fort Valley State University, over the summers of 2008-10. Training was also provided to three University of Florida undergraduate Honors students; two female and one Hispanic. We also provided training to three postdoctoral associates during the funding period. One is now employed in industry, a second is about to take an Assistant professor position and the third is still employed by the University of Florida.
